IX. Visit to SEBI

SEBI  invites  students  from  schools, 
colleges  and  professional  institutes  who  are 
interested to learn about SEBI and its role as 
a regulator of securities markets. The program 
was  started  in  February  2011  and  has  been 
quite  popular.  Till  date  SEBI  had  conducted 
80 such visits; and participants visiting from 
different  parts  of  the  country  (Amritsar, 
Pondicherry, Goa, Bareilly, Thrissur etc.) and 
(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:283)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:507)(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:153)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:496)(cid:561)
Management, Commerce, Banking, Law, Arts, 
science  etc.).  Educational  institutions  from 
(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:283)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:343)(cid:561) (cid:23)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:22)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)
(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:344)(cid:342)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:283)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:159)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561)
under this program.

11. RESEARCH ACTIVITIES

Section 11(2) (l) of the SEBI Act enshrines 
SEBI  to  undertake  research  activities  for 
effectively  fulfilling  its  functions.  The 
Department of Economic and Policy Analysis 
(DEPA)  assumes  its  role  primarily  from 
Section 11 (2) (l) and Section 18 of SEBI Act, 

DEPA  is  responsible  to  maintain 
a  repository  of  data  for  entire  capital/ 
securities  market,  collection  of  data  from 
various  sources,  verifying  their  accuracy 
and continuously maintaining/ updating the 
data.  During  2012-13,  SEBI  has  published 
SEBI  Annual  Report  2011-12,  Handbook 
of  Statistics  on  Indian  Securities  Market 
2012  and  SEBI  monthly  Bulletin  which  are 
available  in  the  publication  section  of  SEBI 
website  (www.sebi.gov.in).  SEBI  has  been 
distributing  these  publications  to  various 
stakeholders  in  the  market  like  research 
institutions,  investor  associations,  mutual 
funds,  banks,  etc  on  gratis.  Apart  from 
the  publication,  SEBI  was  responsible  for 
providing  weekly-monthly  report  on  Indian 
Securities  Markets  and  Monthly  Report  on 
(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:282)(cid:152)(cid:160)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:7)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:144)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:148)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:15)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:162)(cid:561)
of  Finance  (MoF).  SEBI  is  contributing 
the  capital  market  segment  on  Red  Book 
Payment  System  in  India  (published  by 
Bank  of  International  settlement  (BIS)), 
Economic Survey for India and Government 
of Maharashtra.

156

Part Three: Regulation of Securities Market

derivatives  segment  like  ‘  Cross  Border 
Transaction  of  Capital  among  SAARC 
(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:514)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:158)(cid:139)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:5)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:496)(cid:561)
Kathmandu.

III. Risk Management

SEBI  has  set  up  Systemic  Stability 
Unit  (SSU)  to  assess  systemic  risks,  if  any, 
(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:148)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:283)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561)

coordinated  assistance/inputs  from  SEBI 
to  FSDC  in  monitoring  Systemic  Risks  in 
respect  of  Securities  Market  and  monitoring 
of  Systematically  Important  Financial 
Institutions  (SIFI)  under  the  jurisdiction  of 
SEBI. SSU is also coordinating with RBI and 
concerned  Departments  in  SEBI  in  respect 
of  circulation  of  agenda  notes,  minutes, 
(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:153)(cid:158)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:6)(cid:5)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:158)(cid:139)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:156)(cid:561)

Financial Stability Report (FSR) published by 
RBI.

158

PART FOUR: REGULATORY CHANGES

Part Four: Regulatory Changes

The  SEBI  Board  has  taken  various 
regulatory  measures  to  protect  the  interests 
of  investors  in  securities  market,  for  the 
development  of  the  securities  market  and 
to  regulate  the  securities  markets.  Various 
amendments to the existing regulations were 
(cid:151)(cid:152)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:281)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:495)(cid:561)(cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:158)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:162)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:162)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)
made is as follows:

1. REGULATORY DEVELOPMENTS

I. New Regulations

A. SEBI  (Alternative  Investment  Funds) 

Regulations, 2012 w.e.f. May 21, 2012
The  Securities  and  Exchange  Board 
of  India  (Alternative  Investment  Funds) 
Regulations (“AIF Regulations”) repealed the 
SEBI  (Venture  Capital  Funds)  Regulations, 
1996  (“VCF  Regulations”).  The  AIF 
Regulations  were  introduced  with  a  view 
(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:148)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:142)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561)
unregulated funds, encouraging formation of 
new capital and consumer protection. The AIF 
Regulations  are  the  outcome  of  the  Concept 
Paper,  issued  in  August  2011,  which  was 
drafted with a view to shift SEBI’s regulatory 
strategy from the existing facilitative regime 
to a mandatory regime.

A  significant  requirement  of  the  AIF 
(cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:561)
raising  capital  from  investors  unless  they 
(cid:152)(cid:139)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:152)(cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561)

(cid:139)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:158)(cid:144)(cid:145)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:514)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:162)(cid:561)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561)
regime: (i) Venture Capital Funds; (ii) Private 
(cid:11)(cid:151)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:18)(cid:158)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:561) (cid:7)(cid:154)(cid:158)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:8)(cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:156)(cid:498)(cid:561) (cid:507)(cid:146)(cid:146)(cid:146)(cid:508)(cid:561)

(cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:561) (cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561)

in the form of a trust or a company or a LLP 
(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:152)(cid:141)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:496)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:156)(cid:561)
from  investors,  whether  Indian  or  foreigner 
(cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:140)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:141)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561)
investment  policy.  Mutual  funds  under  the 
SEBI  (Mutual  Funds)  Regulation,  1996  and 
collective  investment  schemes  under  SEBI 
(Collective Investment Schemes) Regulations, 
1999,  family  trust,  ESOP  trusts,  employee 
welfare  trusts,  holding  companies,  etc.  are 
expressly excluded.

AIF Regulations include:

a.

The AIF shall not accept from an investor 
an  investment  of  value  less  than  one 
crore.

crore.

The manager or sponsor for a Category 
I  and  II  AIF  shall  have  a  continuing 
interest  in  the  AIF  of  not  less  than  2.5 
percent  of  the  initial  corpus  or  five 
crore  whichever  is  lower.  For  Category 
III  Alternative  Investment  Fund,  the

160

B.

Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock 
Exchanges  and  Clearing  Corporations) 
Regulations, 2012 w.e.f. June 20, 2012
The  Securities  Contracts  (Regulation) 
(Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) 
Regulations, 2012 (“SECC Regulations”) were 
framed  to  provide  for  the  ownership  and 
governance  norms  for  stock  exchanges  and 
clearing corporations.

Previously,  ownership  aspects  of  stock 
(cid:142)(cid:161)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:162)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:5)(cid:20)(cid:561) (cid:507)(cid:20)(cid:508)(cid:561)
(Manner  of  Increasing  and  Maintaining 
(cid:18)(cid:158)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:145)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:144)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:140)(cid:148)(cid:561)
Exchanges)  Regulations,  2006  (“MIMPS 
(cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:516)(cid:508)(cid:495)(cid:561)(cid:10)(cid:152)(cid:160)(cid:142)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:496)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:149)(cid:162)(cid:561)
applied  to  those  stock  exchanges  that  were 
corporatized  and  demutualised  in  terms  of 
schemes prepared in pursuance of the power 
under  section  4B  of  the  Securities  Contracts 
(Regulation)  Act,  1956  (“SCRA”).  The  SECC 
Regulations  were  framed  to  provide  a 
(cid:143)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:160)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:148)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:152)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:140)(cid:148)(cid:561)
exchanges and clearing corporations, repealed 
(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:15)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:18)(cid:21)(cid:561) (cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:158)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561)
the  aspects  of  MIMPS  Regulations  dealing 
with  shareholding  restriction  and  fit  and 
proper  criteria.  Since  Securities  Contracts 
(Regulation)  Rules,  1957  (“SCRR”)  already 
provided  for  the  aspects  of  recognition,  the 
SECC  Regulations  cross  refer  to  the  SCRR 
with regard to these aspects.

(cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:146)(cid:144)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:281)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561)(cid:139)(cid:162)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)

SECC Regulations are as follows:
a. Mandatory  recognition  of  clearing 
corporations:  The  SECC  Regulations 
makes  it  mandatory  for  those  entities 
(cid:160)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:308)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:162)(cid:561)(cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561)
recognition as clearing corporations.

(cid:139)(cid:495)(cid:561) Corporatized  and  Demutualised 
entity:  Stock  exchanges  and  clearing 
(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:561)

Part Four: Regulatory Changes

such  as  code  of  conduct,  regulation  of 
compensation policy, etc.

g. Corporate  Governance:  The  SECC 
Regulations  provide  for  methods  to 
promote  good  corporate  governance.

B.

SEBI  (Depositories  and  Participants) 
(Amendment)  Regulations  2012  w.e.f. 
September 11, 2012.
In  line  with  the  recommendation  of 
(cid:4)(cid:146)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:12)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:496)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561)(cid:507)(cid:6)(cid:142)(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:156)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)
and  Participants)  Regulations,  1996  were 
amended  to  incorporate,  inter  alia,  the 
norms  on  shareholding  and  governance 
of  depositories.  The  key  features  of  the 
amendment are as follows:
(cid:343)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:153)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:561)
(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:145)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)
depository.

2. A  person  whose  shareholding  exceeds 
two percent of the paid up equity share 
capital of a depository is required to seek 
(cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:159)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:143)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:138)(cid:162)(cid:156)(cid:561)
of the acquisition.

(cid:345)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:144)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:140)(cid:148)(cid:561) (cid:142)(cid:161)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:561)
a  sponsor  of  any  depository  is  not 
allowed  to  hold  more  than  24  percent 
of  the  paid  up  equity  share  capital 
of  that  depository.  Mandate  on  the 
sponsor  stock  exchange  to  reduce  the 
shareholding  to  24  percent  within  a 
(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:141)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:345)(cid:561)(cid:162)(cid:142)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:495)

(cid:142)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:153)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:159)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)

at  least  five  working  days  prior  to 
opening  of  the  issue,  as  against  the 
current  provision  of  two  working  days 
in  the  case  of  IPOs.  This  will  provide 
more time to the market to analyze the 
issue.

Part Four: Regulatory Changes

f.(cid:561)

B.

a.

(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:155)(cid:140)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:16)(cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:142)(cid:283)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561)
decision of some of the respondents on its 
various representations. It has also noted 
that the various representations made to 
SEBI  were  examined  and  appropriately

174

Part Four: Regulatory Changes

II. Redesigning SEBI’s Role

SEBI  felt  the  need  to  revisit  its 
organisational  capabilities  to  ensure  that 
these  are  relevant  in  the  dynamic  market 
environment.  Accordingly,  SEBI  Board 
approved  the  proposal  to  engage  an 
independent  reputed  consultant  to  revisit 
the  structural  and  organisational  issues, 
re-prioritize  areas  of  focus  and  look  at  the 
technological  and  man  power  needs  with 
the  emphasis  on  attracting  and  retaining 
good  quality  talent.  Consequently,  for  the 
appointment  of  consultant,  a  Consultant 
(cid:7)(cid:159)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:158)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:507)(cid:5)(cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:508)(cid:561)(cid:160)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:158)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561)
by  SEBI.  Based  on  the  recommendations  of 
CEC,  M/s.  Oliver  Wyman  was  appointed 
for  “Redesigning  SEBI’s  Functions,  Role, 
Structure & Vision”.

180

For the monitoring of the project a Project 
(cid:21)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:507)(cid:18)(cid:21)(cid:5)(cid:508)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:158)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561)
on  July  17,  2012  to  look  into  a)  Overall 
project  management  and  communication,  b) 
issues  resolution,  c)  advice  and  counsel  to 
project team and consultants; and d) thought 
leadership and expert input. The designated 
Consultant,  M/s.  Oliver  Wyman  started 
working  on  the  project  since  July  23,  2012. 
The Consultant had several rounds meetings 
with  the  PSC  also  one-on-one  meeting  with 
Whole Time Members and Executive Directors 
of  SEBI  for  guidance  from  time  to  time.  A 
(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:15)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561)(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:507)(cid:5)(cid:15)(cid:5)(cid:508)(cid:561)(cid:160)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:561)
constituted  as  per  the  Ministry  of  Finance/
Central Vigilance Commission’s guidelines.

consultant was facilitated to get inputs from 
(cid:150)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:158)(cid:150)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:159)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:159)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:283)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:156)(cid:156)(cid:561)
all  functions  and  seniority  levels  and  to

which  includes  brokerage  houses,  wealth

in  institutional  broking  and  merchant

recommendations with Dy. Governor, Reserve 
Bank of India, Shri Anand Sinha on December

V.

Job Rotation
HRD  division  undertook  the  exercise 
of  job  rotation  during  the  year.  A  total  of 
222  officers  were  rotated  among  different 

role  with  prime  focus  on  implementation 
of  policies  on  capacity  building,  training, 
promotions, placement and transfers.

members. Scheme for purchasing computers 
/ computer-related items has been introduced 
for  all  staff  members  including  those  on 
contract/deputation.  Paternity  leave  has 
been  introduced  for  male  staff  members.

allowance  have  been  introduced  for  staff 
members transferred at the Board’s instance.

of  vehicle  maintenance  expenses  has 
been  revised  for  Executive  Directors;  also 
reimbursement  towards  driver’s  salary  has

felicitated  with  the  National  Award  in 
the  Category  of  Best  Employee  by  the 
Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment, 
Government of India.

social responsibility

Mahatma  Gandhi  Seva  Mandir  Blood  Bank, 
organised a blood donation drive. It received 
an  overwhelming  response  from  staff 
members  with  about  90  donors  voluntarily 
giving blood. Visits were made to NGOs like

Annual Report 2012-13

IV. In addition to the NISM Online Admission 
Test, the selection basket has been enhanced 
by  accepting  test  scores  such  as  GMAT  and 
XAT.  NISM  had  guest  faculty  from  leading 
organisations  such  as  Edelweiss,  IndiaFirst 
Life,  ING,  KBC  Bank,  Prabhudas  Liladher, 
NSE,  and  Principal  Retirement  Advisors 
(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:140)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:17)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:156)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561)
their expertise. During the year, pedagogical 
initiatives included Simulated Trading, Case 
Studies  from  Harvard  and  other  resources, 
Reviews  of  Financial  Books  and  Financial 
Films,  exposure  to  Database  Software  such 
as CMIE Prowess, Bloomberg and Statistical 
Software  such  as  SAS  and  WINRATS.  The 
library added several new titles pertaining to 
(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561)(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:148)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:496)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:158)(cid:144)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561)
the impressive collection.

(cid:16)(cid:11)(cid:21)(cid:15)(cid:561) (cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:5)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:281)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)
Law  (CSL)  as  a  part-time  programme  for 
working  executives,  across  26  Saturdays, 
at  Nariman  Point.  NISM  had  received 
recognition  as  a  Research  Centre  for  PhD 
studies,  by  the  Symbiosis  International 
University,  Pune  and  a  dialogue  has  been 
initiated with Goa University.

Regulations  –  An  Anti  Money 
Laundering Perspective

and  Exchange  Board  of  India  (SEBI)  and 
Enforcement  Directorate  (ED)  attended

the  programme.  The  topics  covered  under

under  section  12A  of  SEBI  Act  –  A  PMLA 
Perspective.

V.

Initiatives on Information and 
Communication Technology 
(cid:15)(cid:138)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)

A. E-learning Department

National  Institute  of  Securities  Markets 
(NISM)  believes  that  technology  enabled 
learning  can  play  a  valuable  role  in  its 
educational,  training  and  literacy  initiatives. 
Drawing from NISM’s existing experience as 
trainers  of  securities  markets  professionals, 
self study courseware is being developed that 
can  provide  high  quality,  engaging,  online 
learning experience, covering a wide variety 
of topics.

Currently, NISM is developing content for 
Mutual Fund Distributors’ (MFDs) module as 
part of our Continuing Professional Education 
(cid:507)(cid:5)(cid:18)(cid:7)(cid:508)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:283)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:561)
customized Learning management system. This 
course will use a combination of text, image, 
audio,  animation,  interactive  exercises  and 
assessments to achieve a learning experience 
that takes advantage of opportunities inherent 
in online learning.

In  future,  NISM  plans  to  deliver 
E-learning  courses,  covering  wide  variety  of 
topics in the securities markets, as part of its 
various  initiatives  both  in  the  synchronous 
and asynchronous mode.

introduced the Skills Registry portal wherein 
the stakeholders after registration can verify

also  emails  certificates  to  the  successful

E. NSFE Project

To  strengthen  and  institutionalize 
the  mechanism  for  maintaining  financial 
stability  and  enhancing  inter-regulatory 
coordination, an apex-level Financial Stability 
and Development Council (FSDC) was set-up 
in 2010 by the Government of India.

VI. Hindi Magazine

With a view to publish the contributions 
of the winners of Hindi Competitions and to 
(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:144)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:283)(cid:561)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:496)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)
issue  of  Hindi  Magazine  (“Viniyamika”)  of 
SEBI was published during the year.

VII. Information Technology and Hindi
In order to provide the facility to work 
in Hindi more conveniently, advanced multi-
lingual software having Unicode facility was 
made available on all the computers.

VIII.

Investor Website and SCORES

Efforts  are  in  progress  to  make  the 
investor  website  available  in  Hindi  and 
also  to  ensure  bilingualization  of  SEBI 
Complaints Redress System (SCORES), so as 
to make available the investor website and the 
SCORES for investors in their language.

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY

( I T )  
include  strengthening  of  IT  Security, 
implementation  of  new  Webmail  system 
with  the  complete  Disaster  Recovery  (DR) 
features,  implementation  of  two  factor 
authentication  system  for  secured  access  to 
(cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:496)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:149)(cid:152)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561)

I.

Strengthening of IT security
The existing organisational IT security is 
reviewed extensively and the following major 
steps were taken to strengthen the IT security:
a) Conducted  network  vulnerability 

b)

assessment and penetration test
Enterprise  network  architecture  was 
redesigned to include Firewall, Routers, 
Virtual Private Network (VPN) solution, 
Secured  access  to  application  through 
two factor authentication

II.

Implementation of New Webmail 
System
The new Webmail system was deployed 
in High availability mode with complete DR 
Failover capabilities. The new email systems 
not  only  secure  but  also  provide  seamless 
access  to  corporate  email  system  from 

(cid:18)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:8)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:497)(cid:561)(cid:17)(cid:155)(cid:144)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:15)(cid:138)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)

Department  embarked  on  integration  of 
various  application  systems  implemented  in 
SEBI.  The  prime  motivation  for  this  activity 
was  to  develop  a  framework  for  integrating 
information,  people  and  processes  across 
the  organisation.  To  meet  this  objective, 
specifications  for  the  development  of 
Enterprise Wide Portal (EWP) were designed. 
The  planned  solution  architecture  for  SEBI’s 
EWP  is  highly  scalable  and  performance 
driven and will ensure rapid deployment and 
integration  of  future  systems.  The  EWP  is 
planned to be web driven with multi-channel 
(cid:156)(cid:158)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:160)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:281)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:140)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:156)(cid:561)
policy.  The  EWP  is  designed  to  harness  the 
portlet  based  technology  for  aggregation 
and  personalization  of  information  across 
distributed applications in SEBI.

the DR servers

III. Implementation  of  two  factor 
authentication for secured access to 
SEBI Web applications
To  enhance  the  security  of  the  internet 
facing  web  applications  and  to  mitigate 
the  online  security  threats,  the  2-Factor 
authentication  system  is  deployed.  Users, 
apart  from  the  regular  user  id  /  password, 
need to provide the two factor authentication 
code  (which  is  a  combination  of  4  digit  pin 
number  and  6  digit  randomly  generated 
token  code  of  the  physical  hardware  token). 
This  system  was  deployed  both  at  Primary 
site, Mumbai and DR site, Chennai.

IV. Internet Connectivity to DR site 

Chennai
To  enable  DR  Failovers  and  seamless 
connectivity  to  SEBI  applications  from  the 
Internet new leased line internet connectivity 
was provisioned in the DR site Chennai.

I. Association with IOSCO

The  IOSCO  Board,  the  governing 
body  of  the  IOSCO,  is  made  up  of  32 
securities  market  regulator  and  SEBI  is  one 
of  the  members  of  the  IOSCO  Board.  SEBI 
participates  in  the  various  work  streams 
of  IOSCO  and  makes  contributions  to  the 
policy  decisions  on  the  different  issues 
pertaining to the securities market. SEBI has 
its  representations  in  5  out  of  the  7  policy 
committees  of  IOSCO.  SEBI  endeavors  to 
implement  the  recommendations  made  by 
IOSCO through its reports.

192

SEBI  is  a  member  of  the  IOSCO’s

the  Chairmanship  of  Shri  U.K.  Sinha.  The

The  second  meeting  took  place  in  Bangkok, 
(cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:16)(cid:152)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:344)(cid:350)(cid:556)(cid:345)(cid:342)(cid:496)(cid:561) (cid:344)(cid:342)(cid:343)(cid:344)(cid:495)(cid:561)

in  shaping  the  global  policy  framework  for

(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:142)(cid:283)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:495)

As  APRC  Chair,  SEBI  has  brought 
dynamism and a sense of mutual camaraderie 
into  the  working  of  APRC  through  various 
initiatives. A few such initiatives are as follows:
a. An  industry  roundtable  for  frank  and 
constructive  exchange  of  ideas  among

‘identifying  and  addressing  emerging

appropriate  regulatory  response  in  the

on the Implementation of Principles 6 and 7:
Principle  6:  The  Regulator  should  have  or 
contribute to a process to monitor, mitigate 
and manage systemic risk, appropriate to its 
mandate.
(cid:18)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:349)(cid:497)  The  Regulator  should  have 
or  contribute  to  a  process  to  review  the 
perimeter of regulation regularly.
SEBI  along  with  33  other  members 
have  participated  in  this  thematic  review. 
This  Review  is  an  opportunity  for  IOSCO 
and  members  participating  in  the  Review 
to  show  progress  in  implementing  these 

Principles,  share  experiences  of  other 
members’  jurisdictions  in  implementation 
and  identify  and  assess  whether  further 
guidance  is  needed  from  IOSCO  to  support 
implementation.  Further,  SEBI  also  has  its 
representation  as  one  of  its  members  in  the 
Review  Team,  which  is  carrying  out  this 
review.

SEBI  plays  an  important  leadership 
role  in  the  various  activities  of  AC  such  as 
coordination  with  the  member  jurisdictions 
on their participation for the Country Review 
Program, developing strategies for AC and its 
implementations etc.

ordinary  membership.  The  EMC  members 
also  represent  the  world’s  fastest  growing

that the number of IOSCO members that are

II. Association with G20 / FSB

The  Financial  Stability  Board  (FSB)  is 
an international body established to address 
(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:162)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:561) (cid:159)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:151)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:139)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:561)
the  development  and  implementation  of 
strong  regulatory,  supervisory  and  other 
(cid:153)(cid:152)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:138)(cid:139)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:162)(cid:495)(cid:561)
One  of  the  main  mandates  of  the  FSB  is  to 
implement  G20  Policy  announcements  on 
(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:495)

SEBI  is  a  member  of  the  Plenary  and 
Regional  Committee  Group-  RCG  (Asia) 
of  the  FSB.  During  2012-13,  FSB  Plenary 
met  three  times  and  the  FSB  RCG Asia  met 
once.  SEBI  provides  comments  to  the  MoF 
on  various  FSB  issues  since  the  MoF  is  the 
principal  country  member  to  the  FSB  from 
India.  SEBI  is  also  a  member  of  Indian 
Working  Group  formed  by  Ministry  of 
Finance on G20. Further, SEBI also provides 
comments to the IOSCO on FSB mandates.

(cid:21)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:144)(cid:149)(cid:152)(cid:139)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)
crisis, the G20 has established core elements 
of  a  new  global  financial  regulatory 
framework  that  will  make  the  financial 
(cid:156)(cid:162)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:561)(cid:150)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561)(cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:561)

the  needs  of  the  real  economy.  National 
authorities  and  international  bodies,  with 
the  Financial  Stability  Board  (FSB)  as  a 
central  locus  of  coordination,  have  further 
(cid:138)(cid:141)(cid:159)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:150)(cid:561) (cid:153)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:144)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:496)(cid:561)
based  on  clear  principles  and  timetables 
for  implementation.  Major  international 
policy  reforms  of  FSB  have  now  globally 
been agreed, to address risks and strengthen 
(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561)(cid:138)(cid:140)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:156)(cid:156)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:495)

FSB  adopts,  inter-alia,  survey  /
questionnaire methodologies in order to obtain 
inputs for recommending policies, ascertaining 
the feedback and status of the recommended 
policies.  During  2012-13,  FSB  conducted 
various  surveys/questionnaire  including 
on  Client  Assets  Protection  and  Resolution 
Regime Peer Review. SEBI provided responses 
to these surveys/questionnaires.

III. Joint Forum

Following  the  decision  of  the  Joint 
Forum  Coordination  Group,  in  February, 
2012,  SEBI  became  a  new  member  of  the 
Joint  Forum  (JF),  a  cooperative  cross-sector 
group  which  was  established  in  1996  by  its 
(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:153)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:139)(cid:152)(cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:556)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:4)(cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561)
Banking Supervision (BCBS), the International 
Organization  of  Securities  Commissions 
(IOSCO)  and  the  International  Association 
of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS), to deal with 
issues common to the banking, securities and 
insurance sectors, including the regulation of 
(cid:281)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:149)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:495)

SEBI  was  nominated  by  the  IOSCO  as 
(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:148)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:147)(cid:158)(cid:155)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:141)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:150)(cid:139)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:153)(cid:561)

VIII. Foreign Delegations / Dignitaries 
 

 
To  promote  mutual  collaboration 
and  establish  deeper  levels  of  regulatory 
cooperation,  and  to  facilitate  a  better 
understanding  of  the  Indian  securities 
markets,  SEBI  played  host  to  a  number  of 
important  dignitaries  and  delegations  of 
overseas regulatory bodies / agencies.

The  authorities  from  which  delegations 
visited  SEBI  during  the  year  include  the 
–Ministry  of  Finance,  Govt.  of  Japan;  US 
Department of Treasury; CMA, Saudi Arabia; 
SC Malaysia; Govt. of Luxembourg; GIZ and

11. RIGHT TO INFORMATION ACT

SEBI  has  been  implementing  the  Right 
to  Information  Act,  2005  (RTI  Act)  in  its 
true  spirit  since  its  enactment  in  the  year 
2005.  As  per  the  provisions  of  the  RTI 
Act,  SEBI  has  designated  a  Central  Public 
Information  Officer  (CPIO)  at  its  Head 
(cid:17)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:15)(cid:158)(cid:150)(cid:139)(cid:138)(cid:146)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:6)(cid:155)(cid:495)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:13)(cid:158)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:145)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:150)(cid:138)(cid:561)
is  the  present  CPIO  of  the  SEBI.  In  order 
(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:153)(cid:155)(cid:152)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:140)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:142)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)
manner  and  keeping  the  convenience  of  the 
information  seeker,  SEBI  has  also  appointed 
four  Central  Assistant  Public  Information 
(cid:17)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:507)(cid:5)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:11)(cid:17)(cid:508)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:20)(cid:142)(cid:144)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)

and  Ahmedabad.  The  role  of  CAPIOs  is

Act  and  forward  them  to  CPIO.  SEBI  has 
(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:156)(cid:152)(cid:561) (cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:146)(cid:144)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:17)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:153)(cid:153)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:142)(cid:561)

(cid:22)(cid:145)(cid:146)(cid:155)(cid:141)(cid:561)(cid:21)(cid:158)(cid:139)(cid:556)(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)
(cid:5)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:150)(cid:146)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561)(cid:18)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:138)(cid:150)(cid:142)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:152)(cid:151)

Queries/
(cid:18)(cid:152)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:156)

32

(cid:342)

Whole  Time  Member,  SEBI  is  the  present 
Appellate Authority. As  per  the  direction  of 
the  Central  Information  Commission  (CIC), 
SEBI  has  also  designated  the  Transparency 
Officer  and  Shri  P.  K.  Nagpal,  Executive 
Director,  SEBI,  is  the  present  Transparency 
(cid:17)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:495)

Section 4 of the RTI Act casts obligation 
on  every  Public  Authority  to  make  certain 
proactive  disclosure.  SEBI  has  been 
proactively  making  such  disclosure  and 
(cid:143)(cid:158)(cid:149)(cid:281)(cid:149)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:139)(cid:149)(cid:146)(cid:144)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:561) (cid:158)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:21)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:561) (cid:3)(cid:140)(cid:157)(cid:561)
as well as RTI Act. Since its formation, SEBI 
always  believes  in  adequate  disclosure  of 
the  information  in  the  interest  of  Securities 
market  and  the  investor.  The  focus  of 
the  disclosure  is  transparency  and  better 
understanding  of  the  functioning  of  the 

199

Annual Report 2012-13

Regulator and SEBI registered intermediaries 
and other market participants.

SEBI  has  been  proactively  disclosing 
lots  of  information  about  various  aspects  of 
securities market including various activities 
and  policy  of  the  SEBI  on  its  website  i.e. 
www.sebi.gov.in.  Also,  Frequently  Asked 
Questions  (FAQs)  have  been  uploaded  on 
the  SEBI  website  pertaining  to  different 
departments  /  areas  to  help  the  investors 
understand the procedures and terminologies 
of  the  securities  market.  SEBI  has  provided 
SEBI  Act,  1992  and  other  Acts  as  well  as 
various  Rules,  Regulations.  Circulars  and 
guidelines issued there under on its website 
under the head “Legal Framework”. Further, 
all  the  Orders  passed  by  SEBI,  orders  of 
Securities  Appellate  Tribunal  (SAT)  as  well 
as  orders  of  SEBI  Appellate  Authority  are 
available on the SEBI website.

SEBI  has  also  been  taking  various 
steps  for  ensuring  the  transparency  in  the 
functioning  of  the  exchanges  and  other 
market  participants.  In  order  to  provide  a 
(cid:149)(cid:142)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:162)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:281)(cid:142)(cid:149)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:143)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:156)(cid:561) (cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:141)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561)
market participants and for the development 
of the markets, it has been SEBI’s endeavor to 
promote transparency in its decision making.

SEBI’s focus has been on disseminating 
up-to-date  information  to  the  investors  / 
market  through  various  investor  education 
and  investor  awareness  programs.  SEBI  has 
through  its  various  Regulations,  such  as 
the  ICDR  Regulations  ensured  providing 
maximum  disclosure  to  the  investing  public 
in  order  to  take  well  informed  investment 
decisions.  The  Insider  Trading  Regulations 
and  Takeovers  Regulations  provide  the 
senior  officials  /  major  shareholders  of 
companies  to  disclose  their  holdings  on 
a  regular  basis.  Further,  even  though  the 

200

provisions  of  RTI  Act  are  not  applicable 
to  the  non-public  entities,  viz.  Exchanges  / 
market  intermediaries,  the  disclosure  policy 
of  SEBI  requires  these  entities  to  disclose 
on  their  respective  websites  and  otherwise, 
important  details  and  updated  information 
on the material developments and day-to-day 
operations  including  details  of  redressal  of 
investor grievances.

In  respect  of  RTI  applications  received 
by SEBI which are in the nature of complaints 
(cid:550)(cid:561) (cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:142)(cid:148)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:144)(cid:561) (cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:141)(cid:155)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:156)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:143)(cid:561) (cid:140)(cid:152)(cid:150)(cid:153)(cid:149)(cid:138)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:157)(cid:156)(cid:496)(cid:561) (cid:157)(cid:145)(cid:142)(cid:561) (cid:152)(cid:284)(cid:140)(cid:142)(cid:561)
of CPIO voluntary provides guidance to the 
information seeker. SEBI endeavors for proper 
and  timely  redressal  of  investor  complaints 
for which separate designated website for the 
investor  viz.  (cid:145)(cid:308)(cid:153)(cid:497)(cid:550)(cid:550)(cid:146)(cid:151)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:156)(cid:157)(cid:152)(cid:155)(cid:495)(cid:156)(cid:142)(cid:139)(cid:146)(cid:495)(cid:144)(cid:152)(cid:159)(cid:495)(cid:146)(cid:151)  has 
been  set  up.  Recent  measures  taken  in  this 
regard  include  launching  of  SCORES  (SEBI 
Complaints  Redress  System),  a  web-based, 
centralized  grievance  redress  system  for  the 
investors  of  the  securities  market  where  an 
investor  can  make  complaint  /  grievances 
in  electronic  mode  on  the  SCORES  website 
(www.scores.gov.in)  with  facility  for  online 
tracking of his complaint status.

SEBI  has  endeavoured  to  provide  the 
disclosable information within the stipulated 
time  and  there  is  not  even  a  single  case  of 
delay,  although  the  information  sought, 
many  times,  is  voluminous  and  contain 
large number of issues pertaining to various 
departments  of  SEBI  in  a  single  application. 
Wherever felt appropriate, SEBI has provided 
additional information / guidance voluntarily 
to the information seeker about the securities 
market.

The details of RTI applications and First 
Appeal  to  SEBI  Appellate  Authority  during 
2011-12 and 2012-13 are given as under:

(cid:18)(cid:138)(cid:155)(cid:157)(cid:561)(cid:8)(cid:146)(cid:159)(cid:142)(cid:497)(cid:561)(cid:17)(cid:155)(cid:144)(cid:138)(cid:151)(cid:146)(cid:156)(cid:138)(cid:157)(cid:146)(cid:152)(cid:151)(cid:138)(cid:149)(cid:561)(cid:15)(cid:138)(cid:308)(cid:142)(cid:155)(cid:156)

During  the  year  2012-13  also,  the 
Board  took  various  initiatives  to  maintain 
transparency  in  its  functions,  including 
disclosure  of  the  information  on  a  regular 
basis.  The  Board  has  also  taken  various 
initiatives  /measures  for  investor  education 
and  protection  of  the  interest  of  investors 
of  the  securities  market.  These  initiatives/
measures  also  helped  in  achievement  of  the 
objectives of the RTI Act.
